entry.content:
Optional Eyebrow Content
      
      Case Study
    Esri transforms the way businesses use mapping technology to solve problems. When the software company wanted to transform its certification program to better serve its earners, it turned to digital credentials. As a global brand with certification earners around the world, Esri found digital credentials to be the best option for earners to verify their skills, share their achievements, and connect with opportunities.Implementing digital credentials has been hugely successful for Esri. The addition of digital badges has bolstered its certification program, creating branding and marketing opportunities to increase certification enrollments as well as engage with earners. This case study details how Esri created a successful badging program‚Äîfrom platform selection to implementation and program mapping‚Äîand how the organization measures ROI and key outcomes.Esri is a global software company that specializes in mapping and spatial analytics software. The organization‚Äôs ArcGIS software and apps combine mapping and data analytics to deliver location intelligence, and Esri offers a robust certification program to its international user community in the use and best practices of its software.There are many applications for Esri‚Äôs mapping and analytics platform. The brand‚Äôs visual mapping and storytelling tool, ArcGIS StoryMaps, enables users to present a series of maps supplemented with context from photos and copy to tell a full story about a specific geographic information system (GIS) application. It is powerful software that enables users to map geographic information to help every sector, from government entities improving roadway transportation to commercial businesses identifying the best location for a retail store. Most recently, Esri‚Äôs software is helping map the spread of the COVID-19 virus to help companies and communities map their risk areas and responses.Training and certification are critical to Esri‚Äôs engagement strategy, and it has managed an IT certification program for the organization‚Äôs employees, international distributors, global business partners, and customers for more than 10 years. In 2017, Esri launched digital credentialing on Credly‚Äôs Acclaim platform to better serve its certification candidates‚Äîand its earners are taking advantage. Almost 90% of Esri‚Äôs current credential holders are engaging with digital badging in some way‚Äîfrom badge acceptance and sharing to exploring labor market insights related to Esri certified skills.As a customer-focused organization managing a long-running certification program, Esri began looking at ways to better serve the needs of its certification candidates and earners. While it opted for PDF certificates as an initial way to digitally enhance its program, Esri found the static format lacking critical abilities. A PDF did not give the level of verification or integrated shareability with professional networks that could benefit earners. Esri turned to digital badges as the solution for the value they bring‚Äîdigital badges are actionable, have metadata attached to them that verify skills, and are shareable.‚ÄúWith a static PDF, it wasn‚Äôt easy for certification candidates to show their success or showcase that achievement of being certified. The biggest draw of digital credentials was having the verification and simplicity in sharing digital badges on social platforms. It has done a lot for our customers to showcase their talents. And, it‚Äôs given Esri an opportunity to engage with our earners on social platforms like LinkedIn.‚ÄùRoger Mes√©n-Delgado is a GIS specialist and Esri earner who uses software to improve the way his company farms. As a Smart Farming Supervisor at Fresh Del Monte-Pineapple Division, Roger has a range of responsibilities, from configuring apps for data collection to maintaining geodatabases to analyzing data collected from the field. His Esri ArcGIS digital badge helped him verify his skills during the recruiting process and gives him credibility in his role.‚ÄúEarning an Esri digital badge gives me more credibility in my role, especially when discussing a topic related with GIS. Having a digital badge was also helpful during the recruiting process to verify my skills to the hiring manager.‚Äù¬†Roger Mes√©n-DelgadoWhen it came to selecting a digital credentialing platform, Esri chose Credly‚Äôs Acclaim platform for its expertise in three areas: customer implementation and program success planning, marketing support, and Labor Market Insights. ‚ÄúOne of the big selling points for Credly‚Äôs Acclaim platform versus other badging platforms is that there‚Äôs a lot of great support. Our Customer Success Manager from Credly was incredibly helpful in getting us launched and supported us after we launched. There‚Äôs also a great marketing channel team that helped us with messaging, what to put on our website, and how and when to communicate information. Having those support resources is hugely impactful to the overall success we‚Äôve seen.‚Äù says Jessi Mielke.Access to Credly‚Äôs Labor Market Insights was also important to help earners understand the value of an Esri credential in the context of the labor market. The insights give earners access to job openings, salary ranges, related skills, and other opportunities based on the metadata embedded in their digital badge, and Esri promotes this access to prospective certificate candidates as added value.Esri offers more than 25 certifications with digital credentials across its enterprise geodata and ArcGIS software products. All certifications are exam-based, and different levels of achievement are available, from entry level to associate to professional. The program recently started offering advanced specialty exams for certification on specific skills, like GIS online administration, after candidates pass core exams.¬†The Esri team regularly looks at data to ensure the program is effective and hitting internal goals. Every month, Esri reviews internal certification data with external digital badge data available from Credly‚Äôs Acclaim platform. Key metrics the team reviews include the number of certifications and digital badges issued, the number of users with multiple certifications, and the traffic generated by digital badge views.¬†In a survey of Esri certification earners conducted in 2020 by Esri and Credly, 85% consider their digital badge from Esri to be valuable. Earners report experiencing a range of positive job-related benefits from their digital badge, including:¬†earned a raisegot a promotiongot a new jobexperienced job securityexperienced other job-related benefitsbenefited financiallyEarners also report that the shareability of digital credentials is a huge benefit: 82% of Esri earners surveyed report that digital badges allow them to share their certification more easily. And, 44% say that digital badges allow others to find them more easily based on their skills.Jayanta Poddar is a geospatial IT professional who found that earning and sharing Esri digital badges led to multiple job offers. ‚ÄúI shared my digital badges with my professional network on LinkedIn, and also added them to my r√©sum√©. I believe I stand out for jobs requiring expertise in Esri technology, and having Esri certifications in multiple domains gave organizations confidence in my technical proficiency across the ArcGIS platform.‚Äù¬†Poddar was offered Senior Analyst roles from a few organizations, as well as a Pre-Sales Manager role from Esri India that he accepted.¬†Beyond validating his technical expertise, Poddar believes digital credentials continue to help his professional growth. ‚ÄúDigital credentials helped me gain confidence from peers and customers and boost belief in myself. They also give you an edge in moving to a new role in your organization or landing a new job opportunity.‚ÄùIn its IT certification program, Esri‚Äôs top priorities are finding new ways to increase certification candidates and engage with them. Digital badges help with both. First, Esri markets the value of digital credentials‚Äîadditional recognition opportunities to help reach professional goals and access to labor market insights‚Äîto attract potential certification candidates. ‚ÄúWhen digital badges are shared, people are looking at them. That‚Äôs a lot of different eyes looking at your profile on LinkedIn. It could be someone sourcing for a new position or maybe an internal department looking to recruit or recognize the success of a person.‚Äù says Mielke.Ninety-one percent of Esri‚Äôs digital badge sharing happens on LinkedIn via the earner‚Äôs profile or newsfeed, and Esri leverages that sharing to engage with its earners. When earners share their digital badges, Esri will also share the post to help boost recognition and badge views for the individual earner. The program team also uses its social media channels to educate and encourage earners to accept and share their digital badges.¬†During implementation of their program, Esri dedicated time to developing credential metadata and researching skills tags to effectively map digital badges back to certification exams. Esri‚Äôs goal: create badge templates that are focused, but not too narrow, so that credentials are representative of the exam components, have value for candidates, and sync to opportunities via Credly‚Äôs Labor Market Insights.¬†‚ÄúA huge challenge for certification programs is promoting the value of the certification. Credly‚Äôs Labor Market Insights lets us show where skills directly translate into a specific role or within an organization. It‚Äôs another data point we use to help an individual make a decision on how valuable certification will be for them.‚Äù says Mielke.¬†The upfront work during implementation paid off. Twenty-four percent of Esri earners surveyed say that digital badges help them connect to career opportunities. And, 46% of earners say that having access to Labor Market Insights after earning a digital badge makes their Esri certification more valuable.For Esri certification earner Brent Brady, earning multiple Esri digital badges has helped him confirm his product knowledge and instill more confidence with his customers. As a GIS Consultant with Eagle Technology, a distributor for Esri‚Äôs ArcGIS platform in New Zealand, Brady uses Esri products on a daily basis to help provide advice, services, and support to a wide range of customers in both the private and public sectors.¬†‚ÄúI think the biggest benefit of earning a digital credential is confirming the associated knowledge to help me in my daily role and professional development.‚Äù says Brady. ‚ÄúHaving digital badges allows customers I have not dealt with previously to get a quick understanding and verification of my areas of knowledge and build confidence in the level of assistance they are receiving.‚Äù¬†After earning his digital badges, Brady shared them on LinkedIn and added them to his email signature. And, he has plans of earning additional digital badges for Esri‚Äôs Enterprise System Design. ‚ÄúAttaining the digital badges helps instill a level of confidence in myself and my abilities. The certification tests are not easy, and there is a great degree of satisfaction in knowing that you have the knowledge required to achieve the accreditation.‚Äù says Brady.Digital badging also gives Esri new marketing opportunities. When launching its digital badging program, Esri was able to promote something new to candidates. And, this new offering invigorated its messaging to candidates who hadn‚Äôt been certified in a while or engaged with its brand recently.¬†One successful tactic: encouraging individuals who had earned an older Esri certification (before it had a digital credentialing program) to pursue a new certification to get a digital badge. The promotion was positively received, as individuals wanted that digital badge to more easily share and promote their skills.¬†Digital credentials are a key component in the success of Esri‚Äôs certification program. Its earners want to be able to share their skills, get recognized for their achievements, and connect to professional opportunities, and digital credentials empower them to do all of these.
           
        
          
          
            Case Study
          
           
        
           
        Credly by Pearson hosts the largest and most-connected digital credential network. We help the world speak a common language of verified knowledge, skills, and abilities.

M√°quinas de Soporte Vectorial

Una introducci√≥n a m√©todos supervisados.

La t√©cnica de m√°quinas de soporte vectorial hab√≠a sido por mucho tiempo el frente del caballo de batalla de el machine learning. Luego se extendi√≥ al campo del data mining y en conjunto con otras t√©cnicas forman la ciencia de datos. El deep learning lleg√≥ a sustituir est√° t√©cnica posteriormente.

Vladimir Vapnik es el proponente del m√©todo, trabaj√≥ en AT&T Bell Labs donde hace su propuesta para hacer regresi√≥n y clasificaci√≥n con m√°quinas de soportes, fue muy popular y actualmente ya ha sido superado. Sin embargo, a√∫n es una buena soluci√≥n para algunos casos de¬†estudio.

Inician con una idea que se conoc√≠a en su momento, est√° t√©cnica se llama An√°lisis Discriminante. Esto quiere decir que se busca encontrar un hiperplano que supere a las clases con el mayor margen posible (Ver figura1).

A nivel te√≥rico todo MSV(M√°quinas de Soporte Vectorial) es construido en la idea de que solamente existen dos categor√≠as(por facilidad matem√°tica), sin embargo, esta t√©cnica funciona para n categor√≠as.

Una de las cosas que agrega este m√©todo, es que va encontrar un plano de separaci√≥n con margen m√°ximo. Se utiliza el principio de cercan√≠a invertido. En este caso tenemos un margen que divide las categor√≠as.

Lo que se busca es encontrar la ecuaci√≥n de un hiperplano, que divida las clases y tenga un margen m√°ximo. Despu√©s esa ecuaci√≥n se utiliza para clasificar los nuevos elementos dependiendo de d√≥nde se ubiquen dentro del¬†plano.

¬øC√≥mo funciona?

Usando 2 puntos se pueden calcular y=mx + b y as√≠ con los puntos en el plano poder calcular la formula de la pendiente (m=(Y2-Y1)/(X2-X1)) y luego b para calcular la recta de separaci√≥n (figura 2). Luego se hacen traslaciones sobre las rectas de margen. Luego se puede extraer el hiperplanos no √≥ptimos. En esos casos se busca el hiperplano con error m√≠nimo. Esto es importante recalcar, recordemos que estamos haciendo un modelado y en la realidad pocas veces tenemos una predicci√≥n perfecta.

Esta funci√≥n discriminante lineal podemos tener muchas, sin embargo siempre se debe de tener el margen m√°ximo y que se equivoque lo m√≠nimo posible (figura¬†3).

¬øQu√© ocurre cuando los datos no son linealmente separables?

Cuando los datos est√°n con esta condici√≥n, se pueden utilizar una transformaci√≥n (proyecci√≥n) con una funci√≥n n√∫cleo o Kernel (a esto tambi√©n se conoce como el truco del n√∫cleo) para transformar los datos y as√≠ poder separarlos.

En Python y R se tienen tres o cuatro posibles n√∫cleos (figura 3), inclusive si fuera requerido se puede programar un kernel con el teorema de Marcer. Este da condiciones necesarias y suficientes para tener un f sea un n√∫cleo o¬†kernel.

entry.title: SAR‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUna Introducci√≥n
entry.content:
SAR‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUna Introducci√≥n

De los sensores remotos al Radar de Apertura Sint√©tica(SAR)

Generalidades:

Este art√≠culo pretende dar una base conceptual para iniciar el proceso de aprendizaje en el caminos de SAR, es el primero de varios dentro de los que se espera tener una pr√°ctica que permita complementar la informaci√≥n ac√° brindada. Adem√°s, servir de repositorio de varios documentos que permiten indagar a profundidad sobre el¬†tema.

Espectro Electromagn√©tico

Es un concepto que permite definir energ√≠a radiante con respecto a su longitud de onda o frecuencia. Los valores de longitud de onda son continuos pero se clasifican por medio de secciones donde se comportan de manera similar: Espectro Visible, Infrarojo y micro-ondas (ver figura¬†1).

El espectro Visible (0,4‚Äì0,8 ¬µm): B√°sicamente es denominado as√≠ por ser el √∫nico visible para nosostros como seres humanos. Dentro de esta secci√≥n hay 3 subcategor√≠as: A(0,4¬µm‚Äì0,5¬µm) V(0,5¬µm‚Äì0,6¬µm) y R(0,6¬µm-0,7¬µm). Estos tres ser√≠an los valores primarios que nuestros ojos observan (ver figura¬†1).

Infrarrojo Cercano (0,7¬µm-1,3¬µm): esta banda permite identificar entre masas vegetales y concentraciones de¬†humedad.

Infrarrojo Medio (1,3¬µm-8¬µm): Se utiliza para identificar focos de energ√≠a elevados, como por ejemplo incendios forestales y volcanes en erupci√≥n.

Infrarrojo Lejano (8¬µm-14¬µm): sirve para detectar la mayor parte de las cubiertas terrestres.

Borde Rojo(712¬µm‚Äì722¬µm): es una banda que en los √∫ltimos a√±os se ha estudiado como indicador de la clorofila en las plantas. Esta banda permite identificar de forma temprana enfermedades en¬†plantas.

Micro-Ondas (mayor a 1 mm): son ondas de gran tama√±o, esto permite que penetren en zonas con nubosidad. Estas son las longitudes de onda que se revisan a¬†detalle.

Un punto muy importante es la relaci√≥n de longitud de onda vrs la frecuencia, a mayor longitud de onda menor frecuencia y a mayor frecuencia mayor¬†energ√≠a.

Radar Pasivo: Emisi√≥n de energ√≠a en microondas emitidas por la superficie terrestre o por objetos. Es decir un objeto se calienta y emite en ciertas longitudes de onda y esto hace que se detecten, longitudes de onda¬†altas.

Radar Activos: un sensor emite su propia radiaci√≥n y esta choca contra el receptor(mide la se√±al, esta se√±al de regreso se llama retrodispeci√≥n). El radar activo tiene una gran capacidad de medir caracter√≠sticas f√≠sicas del terreno. Los radares de hoy en d√≠a poseen una gran resoluci√≥n.

SAR, ¬øpor qu√©? y algunos principios b√°sicos

Atenuaci√≥n: es la perdida energ√©tica que tiene una onda al viajar sobre un medio, sea la atm√≥sfera u otro medio. Este factor hace que el uso de SAR tenga una gran ventaja ya que no es absorbido por la nubosidad o por alg√∫n factor atmosf√©rico.

La dispersi√≥n y coeficiente retro-disperci√≥n: Cuando se hace teledetecci√≥n con radar tenemos que tomar en cuenta que es diferente a la √≥ptica. Esta √∫ltima al tener longitudes de onda cortos es pr√°cticamente reflejada. Sin embargo, las longitudes de onda del radar son tan grandes que pueden penetrar la superficie (Ver Figura 3). De forma que la dispersi√≥n ser√≠a el resultado de la combinaci√≥n con la superficie afectada, su interior o composici√≥n y forma geom√©trica.

Un principio importante con esto es que a mayor sea la rugosidad de la superficie mayor ser√° la retro-dispersi√≥n y con ello mayor brillo tendr√° en la imagen generada. De igual manera las superficies lisas reflejan poca energ√≠a de vuelta, esto las hace verse en tonos grises oscuros. En el caso de la vegetaci√≥n como se observa en la figura 3 tiene una rugosidad moderada por lo que se denota en colores grises claros (Instituto Geogr√°fico Espa√±a, 2018 pag.¬†10).

La constante diel√©ctrica es un valor que tienen los objetos o superficies a la hora de reflectar la energ√≠a. Por ejemplo: el agua y los objetos met√°licos tienen un valor alto (80) mientras que un suelo seco tienen esta variable baja (3‚Äì8). Esto nos sirve para entender la humedad en el suelo y la diferencia en zonas boscosas contra deforestadas.(Instituto Geogr√°fico Espa√±a, 2018 pag.¬†10)

Geometr√≠a b√°sica de¬†SAR

SLAR desarrollados en los 50, transportada en una aeronave de forma lateral, estos permit√≠an reconocer objetos debajo de la cobertura. Estos transmiten haces estrechos con forma abanico desde el avi√≥n. Tenemos 3 √°ngulos importantes: incidencia, observaci√≥n y depresi√≥n.

El √Ångulo de Incidencia es el que entra en la direcci√≥n de iluminaci√≥n del radar y la vertical sobe la superficie del terreno (Ver Figura 4). Este √°ngulo toma en cuenta la inclinaci√≥n local de la superficie. Influye en la intensidad de la imagen en cada¬†pixel.

Otros factores importantes de este √°ngulo est√°n relacionados con los efectos sobre la dispersi√≥n en la superficie que tienen, estos son que tendr√° una 1. dispersi√≥n fuerte con un √°ngulo de incidencia bajo, 2. cuanto m√°s √°spera la superficie m√°s lenta ser√° la reducci√≥n y finalmente, 3. se reduce con el incremento en el √°ngulo de incidencia (Instituto Geogr√°fico Espa√±a, 2018 pag.¬†11).

Cuando hablamos de im√°genes de radar tenemos que tener en cuenta que existen 2 tipo de resoluci√≥n. En rango, es el pixel generado a ra√≠z del Swath o √°rea iluminada y la resoluci√≥n en azimut, esta es la que hace referencia a la resoluci√≥n asociada con la direcci√≥n de vuelo y el √°rea que este impacta con cada env√≠o de energ√≠a (Woodhouse, 2006).

Gracias al efecto Doppler permiti√≥ hacer un cambio en la tecnolog√≠a para la recolecci√≥n de las im√°genes de radar. Y es a partir de este punto que se inician la tecnolog√≠a de Radar de Apertura Sint√©tica que nos permite recolectar informaci√≥n como si fuera una antena de mayor¬†tama√±o.

Las microondas tienen diferentes bandas estas son porciones de longitud de onda que son detectadas por los sensores, estos sensores son espec√≠ficos para cada una de las aplicaciones que se quiere. Recordemos que las diferentes bandas tienen diferentes aplicaciones, algunos ejemplos de bandas son:K, Ka, Ku, X, C, S, L y¬†P.

Para el caso de la X (3,8cm ‚Äì2,4cm), es una banda que se usa para el monitoreo de urbanizaci√≥n, masas de hielo y nieve (ver figura 5). La C(7,5cm‚Äì3.8cm) es una banda muy generalista que funciona para el monitoreo de cambios en vegetaci√≥n y movimiento en navegaci√≥n sobre el mar. L(30cm-15cm)es una banda de alta penetraci√≥n utilizada principalmente para la biomasa sobre algunas zonas boscosas. Permite ver el cambio cuando por ejemplo se da la tala(NASA ARSET,¬†2017).

Polarizaci√≥n: La polarizaci√≥n es la forma en la que se env√≠a y recibe las ondas, estas ondas pueden mezclarse para combinar estas 2 opciones(Woodhouse, 2006).

Errores de captura con¬†SAR:

Con esta gran tecnolog√≠a tenemos tres errores principales que se relacionan. Estos son el desplazamiento de estructuras, la inversi√≥n por relieve, la sombra y el¬†moteado.

El desplazamiento de estructuras (foresthortening) se da cuando una pendiente est√° orientada al sensor y aparece acortada en la imagen. Este efecto disminuye con el aumento en el √°ngulo de incidencia. El otro es el de inversi√≥n por relieve (layover), se da cuando tenemos un cambio abrupto en el terreno haciendo que el punto m√°s alto llegue primero que el enviado en un punto m√°s bajo. Este se corrige con aumento en el √°ngulo de incidencia. Finalmente, tenemos la sombra (shadows); esta est√° relacionada con la parte que no se puede observar en una √≥rbita y que deja sin visualizar un punto de los datos recolectados (NASA ARSET,¬†2017).

El moteado (Speckle) es un ruido granular inherente que degrada la resoluci√≥n de la imagen SAR.
